title-group.article-title: Bakhtin, Temporality, and Modern Narrative: Writing "the Whole Triumphant Murderous Unstoppable Chute"

The Theory of the Novel, Georg Lukács

Bakhtin also discusses time and narrative in "The Bildungsroman and Its Sig- nificance in the History of Realism (Toward a Historical Typology of the Novel)."
Bakhtin
The Bildungsroman and Its Significance in the History of Realism (Toward a Historical Typology of the Novel)
Clark and Holquist first note the connection between the discourse and chronotope theories very briefly in discussing literary evolution (288) 288

Holquist notes: "Although conscious retrospectivism is enormously important in literary history in such schools as neoclassicism, or in such writers as Walter Scott, it is perhaps the unconscious turn to the past that has proved most frequent and most consequential" (129). 129
The Sound and the FuryThe Sound and the Fury
The Sound and the FuryThe Sound and the Fury
Philip Weinstein aptly comments that Dilsey "fulfills a white fantasy of a black woman essentially at ease and functioning within a patriarchal world" (85). 85
The Sound and the FuryThe Sound and the Fury
